user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 14.3 is: Controlling expressions shall not be invariant.
Here are exceptions to this rule:
1. Invariants that are used to create infinite loops are permitted.
2. A do-while loop with an essentially Boolean controlling expression that evaluates to false and satisfies the constraints and semantics for an integer constant expression is permitted.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of metal_tests_run:
```c
int metal_tests_run(struct metal_init_params *params)
{
	struct metal_init_params dparams = METAL_INIT_DEFAULTS;
	struct metal_test_case *test_case;
	struct metal_list *node;
	int error, errors = 0;
	const char *dots = "..................................";
	const char *pad;

	if (!params)
		params = &dparams;

	params->log_level = METAL_LOG_DEBUG;
	error = metal_init(params);
	if (error)
		return error;

	metal_list_for_each(&test_cases, node) {
		test_case = metal_container_of(node, struct metal_test_case,
					       node);
		pad = dots + strlen(test_case->name);
		metal_log(METAL_LOG_INFO,"running [%s]\n", test_case->name);
		error = test_case->test();
		metal_log(METAL_LOG_INFO,"result [%s]%s %s%s%s\n",
		       test_case->name, pad,
		       error ? "fail" : "pass",
		       error ? " - error: " : "",
		       error ? strerror(-error) : "");
		if (error)
			errors++;
	}

	metal_finish();

	return errors;
}
```
</target_code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: The only iteration construct in the function is the metal_list_for_each(...) loop, and its macro expansion must be inspected to ensure the loop's controlling expression is not invariant; therefore the whole loop block is reported. Other conditional and expression uses are not suspicious for Rule 14.3: - if (!params) depends on the incoming parameter and is not invariant. - The if (error) checks a variable that changes (set by test_case->test()), so it is not invariant. - The ternary operators in the logging calls use 'error' which is variation per iteration and therefore not invariant. - Assignments (pad = dots + strlen(...)), function calls (metal_init, metal_finish, metal_log, strerror) and the final return errors are not loop controlling expressions and do not constitute invariant controlling expressions under Rule 14.3. No do-while constant-expression or explicit infinite-loop constructs (which would be allowed by the exceptions) are present elsewhere in the function.
